oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Rear court at Clifton Place
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Detail of the rear court at Clifton Place. Shows the exterior of the gable and chimney construction of the two-story brick house on a stone foundation. Stairs lead to a back porch. The twin brick chimneys are joined by a brick parapet.

Clifton Place, named after the Clifton Turnpike, was the antebellum home of General Gideon J. Pillow (1806-1877). The original Greek Revival style home was built by Nathan Vaught in 1838, and the home had several later additions. During the Civil War, it was confiscated by the Federal government, but it was returned to General Pillow after the war.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Eason, W. Jeter
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Dwellings--Tennessee; Architecture, Domestic--Tennessee; Greek revival (Architecture); Clifton Place Plantation (Maury County, Tenn.); Plantations--Tennessee
Houses; Courtyards; Porches; Outbuildings; Chimneys; Parapets
